			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yoast_wpseo_title]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The Storm is Intensifying]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Sea Freight vs. Air Freight</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/sea-freight-vs-air-freight/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Nov 2015 13:28:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=397</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">Whether you are moving abroad or sending products to clients, there are two ways to ship items vast distances: air or sea.</h3>

<p>Both have pros and cons, with container shipping costs and speed being the most crucial factors for businesses. Despite digital hyper-connectivity and budget airlines, our reliance on sea freight has gone virtually unchanged.</p>



<p>Travel between continents was once a shipping monopoly until passenger flights became more affordable. Faster, larger, more efficient planes soon made consumer ocean travel, as a common form of transport, virtually obsolete. Sea travel became a holiday activity, on-board floating towns, around the Caribbean, Mediterranean and to Alaska.</p>



<!--more-->

<p style="margin-top: -28px;">Meanwhile, this <a href="http://kontainers.com/shipping-before-containers/">transport revolution</a> barely touched the freight shipping industry. <em>Ninety percent of everything is still sent in merchant ships.</em></p>



<p>However, that doesnt mean air freight isnt a valid alternative for sending products abroad. Lets take a look at the advantages and disadvantages of both forms of transport</p>



<h3>Pros and Cons of Air Freight vs. Sea Freight</h3>



<h4>Speed</h4>



<p>Planes are, naturally, quicker. Even the longest flights would ensure delivery within 24 hours when being sent direct. In comparison, you could be waiting weeks or months for sea freight to arrive.</p>



<h4>Cost</h4>

<p>Planes have limited cargo holds compared to ships. Even planes dedicated to cargo, are much smaller than sea freight carriers. Consequently, air freight will always be considerably more expensive.</p>



<p>Sea freight is a sector with tight margins, which results in these competitive costs savings being passed onto the customer.</p>



<h4>Reliability</h4>



<p>Planes stick to schedules. Being late is not only inconvenient but costly. Missing landing and take-off slots, spending too long on the tarmac, all impacts the bottom line. Both are industries with tight margins, but sea freight carriers arent penalised for being late.</p>



<img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-399" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/qBUS7gZyT56yoqGcdnyX_airlines-1024x597.jpg" alt="Air freight Reliability" />



<p>The nature of the sea and weather means schedules are more like guidelines where ships are concerned. Sea freight carriers can make stops en route. A lot can happen between your goods being loaded in one port and you collecting them at another</p>



<h4>Environmental Impact</h4>



<p>Air freight is considerably more harmful to the environment, particularly when it comes to CO2 emissions.</p>



International Maritime Organisation (IMO) <a href="http://www.worldshipping.org/benefits-of-liner-shipping/low-environmental-impact" target="_blank">studies have found</a> that shipping only <em>accounts for 2.7% of annual global greenhouse gas emissions.</em>



<p>A ton of goods can be shipped from Melbourne, Australia to Long Beach, California (7,935 miles), whilst generating less CO2 emissions than a truck carrying the same goods from Dallas, Texas (1,442 miles). A bottle of wine served in New York from France has a smaller carbon footprint than a bottle flown from California, according to wine industry reports.</p>



<p>According to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/apr/06/aviation-q-and-a" target="_blank">numerous scientific studies</a>, aviation is responsible for 6.3% of CO2 emissions, although numerous journalists and academics think that <em>6.3% is likely to be a strong underestimate.</em></p>



<a href="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/pollution1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-457" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/pollution1-1024x636.jpg" alt="Pollution" /></a>



<h4>Convenience</h4>



<p>Most of the time, planes depart and land on schedule. Once your goods are loaded, theyre easy to track. Booking air freight is considerably easier, with no other unexpected costs.</p>



<p>Booking a sea freight shipment on the other hand would traditionally involve a freight forwarder, which in turn means having to deal with dozens of emails, calls, and lots of paperwork. Its time-consuming, lacks transparency, and forget about being able to compare quotes quickly or easily. Things are finally changing with this however, as the industry moves into the online digital space and removes middle men from the equation.</p>

  

<h4>Usage</h4>



<p>For the most part, both air and sea freight can accommodate the same cargo, however there are a few key factors which limit air shipping as a valid option. Air freight has much stricter volume and dimension restrictions which means that if the quantity or size of your goods is too great, then youll have no option but to ship via sea. Other products which are classified as <a href="https://kontainers.com/shipping-hazardous-materials/">hazardous or dangerous goods</a> also apply further restrictions than sea freight.</p>



<p>Its quite common as well to have to rely on a freight forwarder (which can be an added inconvenience) as many companies dont allow customers to book directly with an airline unless they have their own transport department that can issue the required documentation (such as airway bill). For smaller shipments, youll most often have to turn to your freight forwarder to provide an LCL quote as well negotiate space allocation and rates.</p>

  

<h3>Air Freight vs. Sea Freight: Competition or Complimentary?</h3>



<p>The invention of cars didnt mean trains and buses stopped running. Airbnb and Uber havent and wont destroy the taxi and hotel industries. Human needs evolve; disruptive ideas force innovation, but air travel was never going to break the shipping industry.</p>



<p>They compliment one another. Passenger airlines carry people; ships carry oil, gas, goods and products around the world. Planes simply give those who need (and can afford the cost) a faster alternative for sending products around the world.</p>



<p>Sea freight shipping times are already factored into the smooth running of the global economy, which means Samsung smartphones dont need to get from South Korea to San Francisco any faster than they already do.</p>



<p>Shipping isnt going anywhere  certainly not sea freight, its only transitioning to to be a faster and efficient process now that a new wave of pioneers are entering the arena to push the industry up to date with the 21st century through digital innovation.</p>



<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>397</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-11-10 13:28:24]]></wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[air freight, freight forwarder, container shipping costs, freight shipping, reefer container, LCL quote, sea freight]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_aioseop_opengraph_settings]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:12:{s:32:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_title";s:0:"";s:31:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_desc";s:0:"";s:36:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_customimg";s:0:"";s:37:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_imagewidth";s:0:"";s:38:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_imageheight";s:0:"";s:32:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_video";s:0:"";s:37:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_videowidth";s:0:"";s:38:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_videoheight";s:0:"";s:35:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_category";s:7:"article";s:34:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_section";s:0:"";s:30:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_tag";s:0:"";s:34:"aioseop_opengraph_settings_setcard";s:7:"summary";}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Drugs and Hackers</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/drugs-and-hackers/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Nov 2015 12:53:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=477</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">How smugglers have gone high-tech</h3>



<p><strong>In 1971, American President Richard Nixon, concerned about drug use amongst soldiers in Vietnam, declared drugs <em>public enemy number one.</em></strong></p>



<p>Ever since, governments, police and military have been engaged in a war on drugs. An expensive war, with no end in sight. A United Nations study, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2011/jul/24/war-on-drugs-40-years" target="_blank"> published in 2011</a>, found the industry to be the third largest in the world, worth 198 billion a year.</p>



<!--more--> 



<p style="margin-top: -28px;">According to a UN report on the subject, there are 230 million drug users around the world. Opiate consumption increased 34.5%, with cocaine use going up 25% between 1989 and 2009.</p>



<p></p>



<h3>How are drug gangs meeting this demand?</h3>



<p>Even with decriminalisation taking place for certain drugs (marijuana) or quantities sufficient for personal use (Italy, Portugal, Netherlands), the transportation of drugs remains illegal.</p>



<p>Drug barons cant just call a freight forwarder and have them collect a truck from Bolivia. You cant carry drugs on a flight and not have a serious exchange with the police and customs officers at the other end. FedEx doesnt offer express delivery for drug dealers either. When it comes to <a href="https://kontainers.com/sea-freight-vs-air-freight/" target="_blank">freight shipping</a>, drug gangs have always had to get creative.</p>



<p>This is the same challenge <a href="https://kontainers.com/how-modern-day-piracy-impacts-freight-shipping/" target="_blank">pirates</a> and smugglers faced. Bootleggers during prohibition ran up against the same problem too.</p>



<p></p>



<h3>Do we invest in our own transport, or smuggle our cargo on-board someone elses ship?</h3>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/smuggle-boats-1024x636.jpg" alt="Smuggling and sea freight" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-484" />



<h4>Option One: Own Transportation.</h4>



<p>Shell corporations can shield a ships owner from law enforcement. Quiet ports can be found, or the most prolific of gangs (like the Medelln Cartel, ran by Pablo Escobar in the 1980s) buy land, to serve as a port or airport.</p>



<p>Escobars criminal empire could afford a network of speed boats, submarines, and planes as a consequence of controlling 80% of 

Columbian cocaine smuggled into the United States during the 1980s.</p>



<p>Most criminal gangs lack that kind of market share, which makes smuggling their last if not only resort.</p>



<h4>Option Two: Smuggling.</h4>



<p>A Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) report found that 60% of shipping lines unwittingly involved in drug smuggling are owned by German, Greek, and U.S. firms.</p>



<p>Hugh Griffiths, co-author of the report, said, <em>This doesn't mean the ship owners, or even the captains, know what they are carrying. But it is relatively easy for traffickers to hide arms and drugs in among legitimate cargos.</em

></p>



<p></p>



<h3>How does illegal cargo get on-board?</h3>



<p>Cargo documents, trust, and an inability to verify make smuggling possible. A reefer container, carrying food and other goods that need to be chilled, could easily be transporting drugs without a captains knowledge.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/load-container-ship-1024x636.jpg" alt="loading sea freight"  class="alignnone size-large wp-image-486" />



<p>Captains have to trust whats in the containers is what the cargo documents claim. Various attempts to scan containers as they arrive in port have proven too expensive and difficult to implement. Less than two percent of 420 million containers are inspected by customs officers. More inspections, despite this being a security concern, would increase container shipping costs, even for those seeking LCL quotes.</p>



<p></p>



<h3>Goods are taken on trust, but with very little verification.</h3>



<p>Meaning smugglers can hide drugs in fish paste, talcum powder, furniture, and other items being shipped. This can be done with or without the knowledge of the owners of the legitimate cargo.</p>



<p>Smuggling operations onboard sea freight ships are getting more and more high-tech. In 2013, a Belgian drugs gang was arrested with two tons of cocaine and heroine, a machine gun, $1.7 million in cash and two hard drives.</p>



<p>It was the hard drives that proved most interesting to law enforcement. Hackers had been hired to track and control the cargo data dock 



workers were seeing in the Port of Antwerp. A security flag was raised when several containers, supposedly carrying bananas, vanished from the port. Since records had been altered, little could be done.</p>



<p>Only after arrests were made, thanks to an attack on the operation by a rival gang, were the details uncovered. Dock workers and freight forwarders were tricked, using a spear phishing attack through emails to install malware.</p>



<p>A firewall didnt prevent further incursions. Police found that hackers broke into the premises to install key-logging and screen grab software, giving them all the information they needed to alter shipping records.</p>



<p>Hardware was also used to scan container numbers near the port, allowing them to easily collect the cargo, with the correct security codes. Ports are a soft underbelly, as far as security is concerned, with freight forwarders reviewing security procedures to avoid the container shipping costs needing to increase due to the impact of hackers and drugs gangs.</p>



<p>Given the volume of drugs being shipped (see map below), a high-tech approach is how drugs gangs avoid detection.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/drug-route-map-1024x643.jpg" alt="Drug route map and sea freight" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-488" />



<h3>What can the shipping industry do?</h3>



<p>Director of Europol, Rob Wainwright, <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24539417" target="_blank">expects the use of hackers and hardware</a> to <em>become a more significant feature [for] future</em> drug trafficking business models.</p>



<p>Hundreds of billions of dollars have gone into fighting organised crime since President Nixon declared war in 1971. Federal resources that went into uncovering Communist conspiracies were used to fight the Mafia in the 1980s, with the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) being used to devastating effect. RICO is one of the worries that kept Tony Soprano awake at night.</p>



<p>The fight against drugs continues, with the same strategies deployed against terrorists and cyber-criminals being used against drugs smugglers. Gangs have gone high-tech, as have the attempts to stop them. One step at a time, shipping is getting more secure. Ship captains will have the same level of verification as airline pilots, allowing everyone to sleep easier at night.</p>



<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>477</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-11-17 12:53:00]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-11-17 12:53:00]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[drugs-and-hackers]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[492]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_aioseop_keywords]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[drug smuggling, international shipping, freight forwarder, container shipping costs, freight shipping, reefer container, LCL quote, sea freight]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yoast_wpseo_metakeywords]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What Are the Most Popular Exports?</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/what-are-the-most-popular-exports/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Nov 2015 14:06:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=508</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">Heres our list of the most interesting (and sometimes surprising) goods and products to be exported from various regions around the world.</h3>



<p><strong>From a trade perspective, borders mean nothing. Relations between countries depend on freight shipping, which operates ceaselessly, rarely stopping for war, diplomacy, Kim Kardashian breaking the Internet, or Cat Memes.</strong></p>



<p>Never in human history have we been so dependent on international trade. Around the world, every country plays a role in a $15 trillion export market. The bulk of these exports, around 90%, are sent as sea freight.</p>











<!--more--> 



<p style="margin-top: -28px;">Take a look at the map below created by Harvard University researchers. You can interact with it <a href="http://globe.cid.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>





<a href="http://globe.cid.harvard.edu/" target="_blank"><img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/the-globe-of-economic-complexity-1024x636.jpg" alt="The globe of economic complexity" class="size-large wp-image-517" /></a>







<p>As the global economy recovers from the recession, our appetite for goods and services marches forward. The independent media outlet, GlobalPost, using CIA World Factbook data, analysed each country's most valuable exports, which means we can understand exports like never before.</p>



<p>Within broader regional data, <strong>we have uncovered some surprise exports, from countries you wouldn't expect producing goods you wouldn't imagine.</strong></p>



<p></p>



<p>In Europe, theres still a surprising amount of manufacturing. Most major Eurozone economies (UK, France, Germany, Spain) produce cars, white goods, machinery, and equipment. Except in Italy</p>



<h3>Italy</h3>



<p><strong>Famous for Kiwis.</strong> Surprisingly, Italy exports more Kiwis than New Zealand, a country known for the brown, furry seed-filled fruit.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/kiwi-fruit-1024x636.jpg" alt="Kiwi Fruit" width="1024" height="636" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-523" />



<h3>France</h3>



<p>Producer of some of the worlds best wine, cheese, and its contribution to life and liberty, is also known for collectables, with over $2 billion spent annually on <strong>French art, antiques, and stamps.</strong></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/art-1024x636.jpg" alt="French Art Exports" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-526" />



<h3>Israel</h3>



<p>The wealth of the Middle East is intimately connected to oil, gas, and other petroleum products. Israel, on the other hand, is the only country in the region without oil, so instead it has become a world leader in computers, security systems and <strong>desalinization technology</strong>.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/security-1024x636.jpg" alt="security system exports"  class="alignnone size-large wp-image-528" />



<p></p>



<p>Africa has long-since been talked about as the final frontier for the world economy. As this map shows, it already produces oil, gold, diamonds and coffee in vast quantities.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/africa-1024x636.jpg" alt="africa"  class="alignnone size-large wp-image-532" />



<p>However, there are a couple of surprise exports that come to mind in Africa</p>





<h3>Ethiopia</h3>



<p>Over one million hectares of land are devoted to <strong>bamboo</strong> plants, often loaded into freight shipping containers for the construction industry.</p> 



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/bamboo-1024x636.jpg" alt="bamboo.jpg"  class="alignnone size-large wp-image-534" />



<h3>Ivory Coast</h3>



<p>In the Ivory Coast, <strong>chocolate</strong> is one of this countries biggest exports. Agri-forestry is now more popular, which protects native plants and wildlife, whilst ensuring the cocoa beans from this region are rich in flavour.</p> 



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/chocolate-1024x636.jpg" alt="chocolate exports" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-535" />



<p></p>





<p>Asia took over from Europe and America as the worlds factory in the latter half of the twentieth century. Globalisation encouraged manufactures to find cheaper cost centres when China was opening its doors to eager Western investors.</p> 



<h3>Japan</h3>



<p>Japan, however, has always had closer relations with the West. One industry where the Japanese are beating Western competitors is Whisky. Scotland, the US, and Canada are famous for scotch, bourbon, and rye <strong>whisky</strong>, respectively. True aficionados would say the only real whisky is from Scotland, but each country, state and province can claim their own superiority.</p> 



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/whisky-1024x636.jpg" alt="whisky exports" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-537" />



<p>The surprise entreat to this market is Japan, once a second rate contender, now consistently winning awards and being sold alongside local brands in supermarkets.</p> 



<p></p>





<p>Across the Pacific, one of the worlds busiest shipping routes, natural resources (beef, sugar, soybeans, and gas) are exported from South America, alongside transport equipment in Brazil.</p> 



<p>In North America, the U.S. economy, whilst being heavily service-based, produces billions worth of high-value capital goods. First ranking economies invest in education and R&D facilities to create products the rest of the world cant: The U.S is no exception.</p> 



<h3>United States</h3>



<p>In the state of Wisconsin, US farmers grow and export tonnes of the Chinese herb, <strong>Ginseng</strong> every year, making it the second largest producer after mainland China.</p> 



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/ginseng-1024x636.jpg" alt="ginseng exports" width="1024" height="636" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-538" />



<h3>Canada</h3>



<p>You might be surprised to learn that Canada, with its millions of acres of farmland, is the world's largest producer of <strong>Feta cheese</strong>, which most people would assume is from Greece. Naturally, Canada is also the worlds largest supplier of <strong>Maple Syrup</strong>, often found in Maple leaf shaped bottles in supermarkets and stores around the world.</p> 



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/MapleSyrup-1024x636.jpg" alt="Maple Syrup exports" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-539" />



<h3>What does this mean for global shipping?</h3>



<p>The maps above provide an idea of what each country exports. The Harvard map is great and fun way to see where these exports go. </p>



<p>Below, this table from the World Shipping Council shows the number of voyages across the major shipping routes, carrying the products and resources we need for our daily consumption. </p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/voyages-across-the-major-shipping-routes-1024x636.jpg" alt=" voyages across the major shipping routes"  class="alignnone size-large wp-image-541" />



<p>In 2013, there were over 61.3 million voyages, shipping everything from oil to cars, diamonds and diamond bracelets, strawberries to ice cream. Shipping specialised products or food, whether it be kiwis from Italy or Feta cheese from Canada, means either using reefer containers or sourcing an LCL quote, when sending smaller cargos.</p> 



<p>The global economy is a complex beast. Keeping it moving is the job of the sea freight industry, without which we wouldnt be able to add to basket in one country and get our iPads and jeans in another.</p>



<h4>Links</h4>



<p><a href="http://globe.cid.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">http://globe.cid.harvard.edu/</a>



<br /><a href="http://www.worldshipping.org/about-the-industry/global-trade/trade-routes" target="_blank">http://www.worldshipping.org/about-the-industry/global-trade/trade-routes</a>



<br /><a href="http://time.com/106666/world-export-maps/ " target="_blank">http://time.com/106666/world-export-maps/ </a>



<br /><a href="http://www.globalpost.com/" target="_blank">http://www.globalpost.com/</a></p> 





<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[what-are-the-most-popular-exports]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Shipping and War</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/freight-shipping-and-war/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Dec 2015 13:11:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=558</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">How safe are merchant ships during times of conflict?</h3>



<p><strong>Many countries, one way or another, depend on imports. Even those with vast resources have consumers eager for the latest gadget, fashion item, or car. More often than not, these are made abroad.</strong></p>



<p>Trade is the backbone of the modern economy, and for trade to function smoothly, merchant ships need to be safe at sea.</p>



<!--more--> 



<p></p>



<h3>When war breaks out, commerce is put at risk since merchant fleets can be attacked, or sunk.</h3>



<p>Most navies were created, in part, to protect merchant fleets, since early mercantile voyages to the New World were often bankrolled out of Royal coffers. Wealthy Europeans had to safeguard their investment. Newly discovered wealth - gold, food, cloth, and spices had to be protected against nations looking to steal another countries riches. </p>



<p><a href="https://kontainers.com/how-modern-day-piracy-impacts-freight-shipping/" target="_blank">Pirates</a> and those vaguely operating under the protection of the law, privateers, attacked merchant ships with little care for treaties hammered out in European capitals. Only well-armed war vessels prowling around shipping lanes made merchant captains and their investors sleep easy at night.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/warshp-1024x636.jpg" alt="battleship threat to sea freight" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-580" />



<h3>These days, ship captains rarely worry about being attacked, except at times of war.</h3>







<p>During both World Wars, hundreds of merchant ships were sunk. The Atlantic, North Sea, the Nordic region, and Mediterranean became a battleground of epic proportions. Allied and Axis ships, navies, submarines, and aircraft were engaged in an ongoing of attacks and counter-attacks.</p> 



<p>Axis forces sought to cripple the UK and deprive the US of Middle East oil. The Battle of the Atlantic came down to gross shipping tonnage: the number of ships Allied forces could keep afloat (whilst hurriedly building new ones), against the number Axis forces could cripple or sink.</p>



<p></p>



<h3>A more recent example, when merchant ships were attacked, was the Iran-Iraq war (1980-1988).</h3>



<p>Known as The Tanker War, both sides were attacking oil tankers and freight shipping vessels in the Strait of Hormuz. Since both countries are dependent on exports, neither would close the Strait, forcing Kuwaiti ships to fly American flags to secure U.S. naval escorts. </p>







<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/bombing-1024x636.jpg" alt="bombing freight ships" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-576" />



<p>At times of war, sea freight captains and shipping lines have several options:</p>



<ul>

<li>

<h4>Seek protection from navies</h4>

<p>Which sometimes, due to where ships are registered (e.g. the flag they are carrying, which for tax reasons are often countries likePanama or Libya) means flying the flag of another country and thereby gaining flag protection from the responsible government.</p

</li>



<li>

<h4>Where possible, avoid the conflict zone</h4>

<p>Ships have been attacked off the coast of dangerous countries in the past, or subject to additional taxes (i.e.: bribes), so for many it is safer to dock in nearby countries, increasing cargo costs for businesses. For example, many ships are docking in Israel or Turkey instead of Syria, due to the war.</p

</li>



<li>

<h4>Find alternative routes</h4>

<p>During World War II and the Iran-Iraq war, that wasnt possible, resulting in thousands of ships sunk (and unseasonably high insurance premiums), but at times, captains can find safer routes, with the subsequent premium on container shipping costs.</p

</li>

</ul>



<h3>How are merchant ships protected?</h3>



<p>At times of peace, merchant ships rarely need protection. </p>



<p>Except in some dangerous waters, such as around Syria (most ships now dock in Turkey, allowing aid to be carried by plane or lorry) or near Ethiopia, where muscled military men sit on the deck with machine guns. Most of the time that kind of protection isn't necessary. Peace is what safeguards our goods, food, and oil.</p>



<p>The world has never been so interconnected. Europe, a continent once torn apart by war for centuries, has seen decades of not just peace, but economic and political interdependence.</p>



<p>Prosperity means that international conflict is, for the most part, handled by diplomats, financiers and lawyers, not generals and armies. In the same way that European nobility used navies to protect ships; capitalism ensures freight shipping vessels sail untroubled because war is an expensive headache the global economy cant afford.</p>





<h4>Links</h4>





<p><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world/from-air-and-sea-iran-iraq-tanker-war-heats-up.html " target="_blank">http://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world/from-air-and-sea-iran-iraq-tanker-war-heats-up.html </a>



<br /><a href="https://www.strausscenter.org/hormuz/tanker-war.html" target="_blank">https://www.strausscenter.org/hormuz/tanker-war.html</a>



</p> 





<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>

]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[freight-shipping-and-war]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_oembed_a09dc5f76679d531f448eccb5455c5b7]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[{{unknown}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_oembed_fc4fb841b6f91ba592f4f7ccf625c0ce]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[{{unknown}}]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yoast_wpseo_metakeywords]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Shipping Before Containers</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/shipping-before-containers/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Dec 2015 13:44:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=631</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">The Lost World of Dockworkers</h3>

 

<p><strong>Sailing up the River Thames, from The Tower of London to Greenwich, takes you around the long curving loop of the Isle of Dogs. The river almost doubles back on itself, with tide controlled waterways cutting through the canyons of steel and glass.</strong></p>



<p>In the modern era, the Isle of Dogs is known as Canary Wharf, a global hub of finance, business and trade, with shops, restaurants, bars and small parks nestled amongst some of the most prestigious corporate real estate in London.</p>



<!--more--> 



<p style="margin-top: -28px;">Rewind history a few hundred years and you would experience a thriving trade hub, very different from the one you wander through today whilst sipping your Starbucks.</p>



<p>A few hundred years ago, this was one of the busiest ports in London. Freight shipping vessels carrying all kinds of goods, from across the Empire and beyond, sailed in and out around the clock.</p>



<p>The river around the port was full of ships, all hoping for enough time to refresh their cargo and weary crew. The many wharfs within the Isle of Dogs were packed with the creaking of hulls, barrels, and boxes being loaded and unloaded, the shouts of captains, traders, and stevedores.</p>



<p>Stevedore is a Portuguese word, derived from Latin, meaning a man who loads ships. This evolved in English to dockworker, and Longshoremen - more commonly used in the US. Even back then, a freight forwarder was a common sight on the docks, haggling with captains and first officers about shipping costs and quotes for their customers.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/sea-freight-Stevedore-1024x636.jpg" alt="sea freight Stevedore" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-636" />





<h3>Shipping Before Containers</h3>



<p>The introduction of containers, resulting in <em>intermodalization</em> in the 1950s, caused what historian John Lewis Gaddis called a moment of punctuated equilibrium. Centuries of tradition were swept away in only a few decades. Ports required only a handful of the workforce that used to depend on the sea freight industry for a living.</p>



<p>Cranes and other automated systems took the work of loading and unloading ships out of the hands of men.</p>



<p>Unloading a freight ship was a complex task in the age of break-bulk shipping. Cargo came in all shapes and sizes, as did ships. Often gangs of at least one hundred men split into teams of twenty were needed to unload a single ship, usually working day and night. Busy ports, such as London and New Orleans, were open all hours.</p>



<p>Securing cargo was an art. Boxes, crates, and barrels were stacked and tied together with rope using a stevedore knot, designed to keep everything in one place during long voyages. These days, containers are fixed in place, unlike container shipping costs which can move around every hour. Even securing space in a reefer container, or getting an LCL quote, can be as changeable as the weather dockworkers had to contend with when loading and unloading ships.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/sea-freight-workers-1024x636.jpg" alt="sea freight workers" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-638" />





<h3>Life and work down the Dock</h3>



<p>Dockworkers usually lived close to the ports, given the plentiful but often casual nature of the work; it made sense to be close at hand.</p>



<p>Safety, although not regulated and monitored like today, was about common sense. Chris Hammond, a former New Orleans dockworker, being interviewed for an oral history project talked about what common sense safety meant. <em>I mean you can hear a strange noise in the middle of a conversation and hear that noise and everyone knows to just start running," said Chris. Because we know that that noise is something breaking, like a cable snapping.</em></p>



<p>Accidents happened, of course, sometimes resulting in fatalities, making the docks a place where everyone watched out for his fellow man.</p>



<p>Not unlike sailors, dockworkers could be transient in nature, with some men finding a way of life working on the ships and docks, free to roam the world. They were the rare ones. Many, like sailors themselves, were dock lifers. Often this ran down through the generations, until the dawn of the container age.</p>



<p></p>



<h3>A Bygone Era</h3>



<p>Between the 1950s and 1990s was an era of unprecedented change for countless industries. After <a href="https://kontainers.com/freight-shipping-and-war/" target="_blank">World War II</a>, Europe and Japan were rebuilt. America went through decades of unprecedented economic growth.</p>



<p>Globalisation and a shift to a service-based economy resulted in many, previously secure jobs being swept away. Technology, automation and outsourcing changed the lives of millions, including dockworkers.</p>



<p>Just as Canary Wharf, London, dozens of former docks around the world have been transformed into areas of high-end real estate, with offices, restaurants, and bars; and just like the old docks, the shipping industry is in the midst of another revolutionary change.</p>



<p>From the 1600s to the 1950s, dock work was a booming industry. Ships were smaller, but cargos needed an army of men to load and unload them. All that has changed, thanks to containers, introduced over 60 years ago.</p>



<p>Now the industry is changing again, as a result of the wider digital transformation society is experiencing.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/sea-freight-dock-1024x636.jpg" alt="sea freight dock" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-639" />



<p>Dock work has been consigned to history, but dockworkers are not forgotten, as they form part of the rich cultural tapestry of our industrial past. With their sweat and hard work, they delivered goods from distant lands, swapping stories, telling jokes with sailors and enjoying the benefits of a hard day's labour. Next time you are buying clothes, sipping lattes, or having a meal in a former dock such as Canary Wharf, give a thought to the hard working men who made these wharfs industrial powerhouses long before the dawn of the digital age.</p>



<h4>Links</h4>



<p><a href="http://www.southernspaces.org/2014/vanished-world-new-orleans-longshoreman" target="_blank">http://www.southernspaces.org/2014/vanished-world-new-orleans-longshoreman</a></p>





<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[The introduction of containers, resulting in intermodalization in the 1950s, caused what historian John Lewis Gaddis called a moment of punctuated equilibrium. Centuries of tradition were swept away in only a few decades. Ports required only a handful of the workforce that used to depend on the sea freight industry for a living.]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Direct Debit Guarantee</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/direct-debit-guarantee/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Jan 2016 16:51:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?page_id=657</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="form_holder">

  <div class="content_holder">

    <div class="row ">

      <div class="twelve columns">

           <h1>Direct Debit Guarantee</h1>

        <div class="page-holder">

        <p>The Guarantee is offered by all banks and building societies that accept instructions to pay Direct Debits</p>

<p>If there are any changes to the amount, date or frequency of your Direct Debit Kontainers will notify you (normally 3 working days) in advance of your account being debited or as otherwise agreed. If you request Kontainers to collect a payment, confirmation of the amount and date will be given to you at the time of the request</p>  

<p>If an error is made in the payment of your Direct Debit, by Kontainers or your bank or building society, you are entitled to a full and immediate refund of the amount paid from your bank or building society</p>  

<p>If you receive a refund you are not entitled to, you must pay it back when Kontainers asks you to.</p>  

<p>You can cancel a Direct Debit at any time by simply contacting your bank or building society. Written confirmation may be required. Please also notify Kontainers.</p>    

        </div>

      </div>

    </div>



    <!-- /contact_info -->



  

</div>



 

</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>657</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-01-04 16:51:16]]></wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[direct-debit-guarantee]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[page]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_page_template]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Shipping Hazardous Materials</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/shipping-hazardous-materials/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Jan 2016 16:47:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=668</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">What you need to know</h3>

 

<p><strong>Shipping hazardous or dangerous materials is no simple matter. The regulations governing this type of sea freight is something most countries are in agreement over.</strong></p>



<p>Safety is everything when it comes to shipping hazardous materials. Although it might be preferable for dangerous products to stay on dry land, the demands of world trade makes that impossible.</p>



<!--more--> 



<p style="margin-top: -28px;">Agricultural products such as fertiliser, need to be moved between chemical plants and farms. Plutonium from Australian mines is required to keep European power stations and nuclear submarines operational. Tankers carrying flammable gasses, petroleum products, and chemicals, traverse the oceans every day, moving from one port to the next to keep petrol prices down and our cars heating and ovens running.</p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/sea-freight-chemicals-1024x636.jpg" alt="sea freight chemicals" />



<h3>Preventing Disasters</h3>



<p>Legislation covering the shipment of hazardous materials has been designed around real and imagined nightmare scenarios. Nuclear material is the most dangerous, which is why specialist carriers are used to prevent accidents or theft.</p>



<p>Next down the list of nightmare scenarios would be a ship carrying weapons or chemicals exploding in a busy port. Sadly, that kind of accident has occurred several times. In 1917, the Canadian city of Halifax, Nova Scotia, was destroyed, resulting in over 2,000 deaths when a French freighter carrying wartime explosives to Europe collided with a Norwegian cargo ship.</p>



<p>Thirty years later, in Texas City, Texas, a freight ship being loaded with 2,100 tons of ammonium nitrate, caught fire and exploded, causing multiple explosions throughout the docks. Over 580 people died.</p>



<p>These are the kinds of disasters that legislation and regulations surrounding the shipment of dangerous goods are trying to prevent.</p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/sea-freight-disaster-1024x636.jpg" alt="sea freight disaster" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-675" />



<h3>How to ship dangerous goods</h3>



<p>When it comes to sea freight, dangerous goods have various levels of classification, which are universal to avoid confusion. These were agreed at the United Nations, to ensure countries were treating hazardous materials with the same care and safeguards at the port of exit and entry.</p>



<p>The burden of legal responsibility falls on the sender, also known as the 'consignor', whos accountable for classifying, packaging and marking any dangerous goods to be transported, according to UK government guidelines. Governments and the agencies responsible for enforcing this legislation use similar language the world over.</p>





<h4>Classification.</h4>



<p>How you package and label goods depends on what you are sending, which means classifying the cargo correctly. This is the International Maritime Organization dangerous goods classification table which all shipping lines use when accepting a hazardous shipment.</p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/un-classes-hazardous.jpg" alt="UN Classes"  class="alignnone size-full wp-image-691" />



<p>United Nations (UN) numbers are also needed, along with flashpoint data (the temperature a dangerous product will ignite, if applicable), ensuring that emergency response personnel are prepared for the dangers of a cargo.</p>



<h4>Packaging dangerous items properly is essential.</h4>



<p>Freight ship captains and forwarders will reject cargo if improperly packaged or labelled. Generally speaking, the more dangerous the goods, the more secure the packaging required. Once contained, the cargo must have the correct labels applied outside, as in accordance to the packaging instructions. The same applies when sending products within a reefer container, which is how medical and other refrigerated cargo is sent, including dangerous or toxic chemicals.</p>



<h4>Appoint a Safety Advisor.</h4>



<p>Whether you appoint someone internally or work with a specialist freight forwarder, there will need to be at least one person responsible for the cargo until it reaches the destination. In the UK, that means assigning a dangerous goods safety adviser (DGSA), who will receive training from the Department for Transport. A DGSA is always required for shipping hazardous materials internationally.</p>



<p>Once the goods have been packaged, <strong>a dangerous goods declaration must be sent to the sea freight company</strong>, to be approved before the cargo can be loaded on the ship.</p>



<h4>Extra Costs.</h4>



<p>Depending on what you are sending and where it's going there will usually be dangerous goods surcharges applied. These extra charges should also cover the cost of handling at the other end, since ports will take extra precautions, depending on the cargo.</p>



<p>When it comes to shipping dangerous goods, theres a lot to consider. Safety is paramount. Shortcuts could result in fines, prison sentences, injury, or even the loss of life. Doing everything by the book, whether you are only sending small quantities or a dozen containers, is the only safe way to ship hazardous materials.</p>



<h4>Sources</h4>

<p><a href="http://www.imo.org/en/Publications/IMDGCode/Pages/Default.aspx" target="_blank">www.imo.org/en/Publications/IMDGCode/Pages/Default.aspx</a><br />



<a href="http://www.hse.gov.uk/cdg/manual/classification.htm#ADR" target="_blank">www.hse.gov.uk/cdg/manual/classification.htm#ADR</a><br />



<a href="https://www.gov.uk/shipping-dangerous-goods/overview" target="_blank">https://www.gov.uk/shipping-dangerous-goods/overview</a></p>





<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Kontainers: Introducing LCL Shipping</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/kontainers-introducing-lcl-shipping/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jan 2016 16:47:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=726</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ <h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">less than container load</h3>

            <p>With the new year, come new announcements! You asked, and we at Kontainers have responded</p>

            <p><strong>The LCL product feature is finally here which means you now have the option to ship either full containers (FCL) or pallets (LCL) through our online platform.</strong></p>

            <!--more--> 

            <p style="margin-top: -28px;">Whatever the size of your shipments, Kontainers provides the same convenience and ease throughout, by instantly connecting you to multiple carriers and real-time schedules and rates, so that you can directly compare and select for the best deals available.</p>

            <div style="width:100%; text-align:center"> <img style="margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;  width:700px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/lcl-screens.jpg" alt="LCL app screen"  /> </div>

            <p>With 90% of all exports around the world being transported through sea freight, its no wonder why were so thrilled to now accommodate both volumes of shipment.</p><p></p>

            <h3>LCL vs FCL: Which one is right for you? </h3>

            <p>Here are some quick points to consider.</p>

            <div class="row compare-shipping">

              <div class="six columns">

                <h5>FCL</h5>

                <img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/intro.png" alt="FCL Freight" style="margin-left:-30px;"  />

                <ul>

                  <li>For any small shipments where cargo can be loaded on to one or several pallets</li><li>Seasonal, off-peak shipments</li>

                  <li>Appropriate for large orders and shipments</li>

                  <li>Useful for optimizing on freight costs</li>

                  <li>Appropriate for wholesale and bulk inventory</li>

                  

                </ul>

              </div>

              <div class="six columns">

                <h5>LCL</h5>

                <img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/lcl.png" alt="LCL freight" style="margin-left: 16px;" />

                <ul><li>For any small shipments where cargo can be loaded on to one or several pallets</li>

                  <li>Seasonal, off-peak shipments</li>

                  <li>Appropriate usually for small individual retail stores, boutique shops with exclusive or limited inventory.</li>

                  <li>Pharmaceutical shipments</li>

                </ul>

              </div>

            </div>

            <p><strong>We're offering 10% off for your first LCL shipment. Click below to redeem your FREE discount code</strong></p>

            <p><a href="https://kontainers.com/introductory_10_percent_off" class="blog-cta">

            <h1>Yes, send me a 10% off discount code!</h1>

            <img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/cta.jpg" style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" alt="Learn more about the Kontainers online platform" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-324" /></a></p>



]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Inside the World of Animal Shipping</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/inside-the-world-of-animal-shipping/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 Jan 2016 14:31:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=770</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">Sea Freight and Anmimals</h3>

 

<p><strong>Worldwide over 700 million live animals are shipped from one location to another, including millions in sea freight containers.</strong></p>



<p>The vast majority of those shipping animals, which includes in specially designed lorries and cargo holds of commercial airlines, are importing or exporting livestock. Cattle, pigs, horses, ponies, sheep and other farm animals, can be transported in sea freight ships, providing this is done safely.</p>



<!--more--> 



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/1-sea-frieight-lorry.jpg" alt="sea frieight lorry" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-773" />



<h3>Shipping Animals Safely</h3>





<p>Not unlike the regulations surrounding hazardous goods, the safe transport of animals is something most countries are in universal agreement over. Most of the time this happens without incident, but in at least 1% of cases, animals can become distressed, injured, or die in transit.</p>



<p>EU regulation, which is mirrored the world over, ensures that animals are transported in a way that wont cause injury or unnecessary suffering. Farmers and the following industries have a legal responsibility to adhere to these rules:</p>



<ul>

<li>livestock and equine hauliers</li>

<li>commercial pet breeders</li>

<li>markets</li>

<li>slaughterhouses</li>

<li>assembly centres</li>

</ul>



<p>How these regulations impact the shipment of animals depends on the length of the journey (both distance and time) and the breed(s) being shipped.</p>



<p>Container shipping costs cover feed, water and other fees, such as veterinary checks and other inspections prior to departure, to ensure animals are healthy enough to travel.</p>



<p></p>



   

<h3>The risks of shipping livestock</h3>



<p>These regulations exist for good reason: when they aren't adhered to, animals can perish. Not only can they go through painful, sometimes cruel and always unnecessary deaths, but this can have negative consequences for the farms involved and the entire food industry also.</p>



<p>More so than ever before, global public opinion is a clear indication that people throughout the world are becoming increasingly unwilling to tolerate the suffering of animals to enjoy cheap hamburgers.</p>



<p>Just recently, 30 export sheep and 3 cattle died on board the MV Ocean Outback, docked in Perth, Australia, bound for Israel. The ship, owned by Wellard Live Exports and chartered by Otway Livestock Exports, encountered engine difficulties while leaving Fremantle port on 29 December 2015, <a href="http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-10/export-ship-offloads-livestock-reports-30-dead-stint-stranded/7079318" target="_blank">according to media reports</a>.</p>



<p>The 33 animals died while the ship was stranded in port for 11 days while engine repairs took place. It was cleared to depart <a href="http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-10/export-ship-offloads-livestock-reports-30-dead-stint-stranded/7079318" target="_blank">following federal and state inspections</a> conducted by a vet, an animal welfare officer, and an RSPCA inspector. Although tragic, given this could have been prevented, the mortality rate was below the 2% allowed for sheep and 1% for cattle, for voyages shorter than ten days.</p>



<p></p>





<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/2-sea-frieight-animals.jpg" alt="MV ocean - animal sea freight"  class="alignnone size-full wp-image-778" />



<h3>Not an isolated incident</h3>



<p>Due to the delay in departure, the original buyer in Israel had to source sheep and cattle elsewhere, resulting in 7,500 sheep offloaded to a pre-quarantine feedlot, while the 5,000 cattle were successfully shipped to a new buyer in South East Asia. Speed is everything when arranging freight shipping for live cargo.</p>



<p>In June 2015, the New Zealand government had to defend a decision to allow the export of 50,000 sheep and 3,000 cattle to Mexico, on board the MV Nada. Despite reports indicating that all arrived safely in Mexico, a country with a severe shortage of breeding livestock due to droughts, animal welfare groups were concerned for their wellbeing.</p>



<p>Currently, New Zealand only allows live exports for breeding, not slaughter, following the death of 5,000 sheep on board a ship bound for Saudi Arabia in 2003. Other busy shipping routes for live animals, particularly between Europe and the UK, are always watched closely by consumer activist and environmental groups.</p>



<p></p>





<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/4-sea-frieight-sheep.jpg" alt="sea freight - shipping sheep" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-780" />



<h3>What about the animals being transported NOT for slaughter or breeding?</h3>



<p>Animals for export, whether for slaughter or breeding, aren't the only types transported on sea freight vessels.</p>



<p>Amid the prospering relations between Canada and China a few years back, the Chinese government sent two Pandas to Canada (on loan) <a href="http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/03/25/fedex-panda-express-is-shipping-pandas-from-china-to-toronto/" target="_blank">using FedEx Express</a>, inside a specially adapted plane as a gesture of goodwill following the $15.1 billion takeover of oil and gas powerhouse, Nexen Inc.</p>



<p></p>





<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/5-shipping-pandas.jpg" alt="Shipping pandas"  class="alignnone size-full wp-image-782" />



<p>Although mainly for zoos, aquariums are now sent using air freight, while some are still moved in ships.</p>



<p>As the documentary movie Blackfish illustrated, Orca whales are routinely transported between aquariums and their natural habitat, the worlds oceans. <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/blackfish/seaworld-orca-whales-finding-dory/" target="_blank">Blackfish wanted to take a closer look at the capture</a>, breeding, and use, for entertainment purposes of Orca whales, following the tragic death of Dawn Brancheau, a trainer at SeaWorld Orlando in 2010.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/6-blackfish.jpg" alt="black fish" width="1024" height="636" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-783" />



<p>She was killed by Tilikum, a 34-year-old bull orca, weighing over 12,000 pounds, responsible for the deaths of two other people while living in captivity. He featured heavily in the controversial movie Blackfish; that has helped bring public pressure on SeaWorld and other live aquarium demonstrations, eventually forcing them to phase out orca shows in favour of conservation-focused shows and educational content.</p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/7-sea-freight-orca.jpg" alt="orcas" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-785" />





<h3>Releasing whales back into the wild</h3>



<p>Blackfish showed us, using footage shot at the time, how young orcas are separated from their families, captured, and shipped in containers filled with water in relatively small vessels, given the size of the cargo. But what about when a whale is fully grown?</p>



<p>In 1998, SeaWorld San Diego set about the task of finding out. They needed to release J.J., a female grey whale they had rescued a year earlier.</p>



<p></p>





<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/8-jj-grey-wale.jpg" alt="JJ the orca" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-786" />



<p>J.J., although still young, had grown to 31 feet, weighing 19,200 pounds (around 7,000 pounds heavier than Tilikum), which made transportation back to the open ocean difficult. The options were dry or a wet container.</p>



<p>Wet is preferable for whales, but presents enormous difficulties, given each gallon of cubic water gallon weighs a little over 8 pounds (not including the weight of the whale).</p>



<p>Releasing J.J., the largest mammal ever transported, back into the ocean meant manoeuvring her inside a custom-made transport sling and lowering her into a 40-foot foam-padded trailer, where she was kept cool and wet for the duration of the journey. She was then lifted by crane into a similar container, specially adapted for her comfort, on board then onto the USCGC Conifer and shipped to an area of open water off Point Loma, near San Diego, California.</p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/9-release-jj.jpg" alt="JJ release" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-787" />



<p>Other forms of sea life, including sharks and smaller whales, however, are more routinely sent in planes, to keep journey times short.</p>



<p></p>



<h3>The future of animal shipping?</h3>



<p>Animal shipping, while important to world food supplies, is more monitored and protected than ever before, primarily to ensure the welfare of the animals in transit. Like New Zealand, more countries prefer to ship meat, rather than live animals for slaughter.</p>



<p>In some parts of the world, including Europe, shipping animals for breeding is necessary to safeguard valuable food supplies - hence, the careful regulations surrounding care, handling, and shipping.</p>



<p>Many other animals, especially those in aquariums and zoos are now sent using air freight, to keep travel time as short as possible, while also ensuring animal care specialists can fly with pandas, sharks, elephants and other captive creatures.</p>





<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/10-elephants-se-freight.jpg" alt="Conservation" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-789" />





<p>Changing public attitudes are also encouraging, as much as possible, a shift away from transporting animals out of natural environments unless necessary for conservation purposes, which one day might altogether change the rolls of aquariums and zoos.</p>







<h4>Sources</h4>





<p>



<a href="http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-10/export-ship-offloads-livestock-reports-30-dead-stint-stranded/7079318" target="_blank">http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-10/export-ship-offloads-livestock-reports-30-dead-stint-stranded/7079318</a><br />



<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/10/live-export-sheep-and-cattle-die-on-ship-stranded-in-perth-for-10-days" target="_blank">http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/10/live-export-sheep-and-cattle-die-on-ship-stranded-in-perth-for-10-days</a><br />



<a href="http://www.fwi.co.uk/livestock/massive-live-sheep-shipment-leaves-new-zealand.htm" target="_blank">http://www.fwi.co.uk/livestock/massive-live-sheep-shipment-leaves-new-zealand.htm</a><br />



<a href="http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/03/25/fedex-panda-express-is-shipping-pandas-from-china-to-toronto/" target="_blank">http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/03/25/fedex-panda-express-is-shipping-pandas-from-china-to-toronto/</a><br />



<a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/blackfish/seaworld-orca-whales-finding-dory/" target="_blank">http://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/blackfish/seaworld-orca-whales-finding-dory/</a>

</p>









<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[797]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_aioseop_keywords]]></wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What Happens to The Worlds Garbage?</title>
		<link>https://kontainers.com/what-happens-to-the-worlds-garbage/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Jan 2016 15:25:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pete@kontainers.co.uk]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://kontainers.com/?p=799</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 class="mobile-sub-heading">How we treat our garbage</h3>

 

<p><strong>Every year, humanity generates about 2.6 trillion pounds of garbage, the equivalent of around 7,000 Empire State Buildings. Cities alone are currently responsible for 1.3 billion tons of that. As urban populations increase, this number is expected to increase to 2.2 billion tons by 2025. </strong></p>



<p>Waste management is a complex issue for developed and developing countries alike, especially when it comes to electronic waste. </p>



<!--more--> 



<p style="margin-top: -28px;">If popular consumer holidays, such as Black Friday and Cyber Monday are any indication, the worlds appetite for the latest shiny gadget can barely keep pace with innovation. It truly is in with the old, out with the new, except this is happening faster than ever before. Sea freight carriers are transporting more and more of the worlds shiny electronics, with demand rising in Asia faster than in developed economies. </p>



<p>Last years flat plasma-screen TV makes room for this years 4K Ultra HD Smart LED TV; theres only so much room in our homes. So, where does all of this electronic waste go? </p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/1-old-tv.jpg" alt="Freight shipping waste - old tvs" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-806" />



<h3>An E-Waste Epidemic </h3>



<p>According to a United Nations report in 2014, we currently generate 50 million tons of electronic, or e-waste, annually, with that expected to rise 33% in the next four years. That equates to 7kg per person. In four years, our electronic waste is expected to weigh the same as eight of Ancient Egypts Pyramids. </p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/2-e-waste-map-3.jpg" alt="Freight shipping - ewaste map"  class="alignnone size-full wp-image-808" />



<p>E-waste includes everything from televisions to fridges, electronic toothbrushes, games consoles, computers, tablets and toys. For over a decade now, dumping e-waste in landfills has been illegal in EU and other developed countries. </p>



<p>Electronics contain too many harmful chemicals, including heavy metals such as lead, cadmium, and mercury. When burnt or crushed, these chemicals can leak into the soil, water, and air - causing great damage to the food chain, environment, and local communities. </p>



<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/3-environment-waste.jpg" alt="Shipping -Environmental waste" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-810" />



<p>Although exporting electronics is legal when they can be refurbished, the UN Step Report found that far too many are being exported illegally. Tired old laptops, tablets, and fridges are being shipped as used goods, although according to Interpol these are non-functional" and "often diverted to the black market and disguised as used goods to avoid the costs associated with legitimate recycling. 

</p>



<p>West Africa and Asia are the primary destinations of these cargos, although no accurate records are being kept, given the illegal nature of this trade. Freight forwarders and freight shipping lines could easily be transporting electronic waste unknowingly, given the methods employed to circumvent reporting requirements. </p>



<p>An inspection of eighteen European seaports in 2005 found that 47% of e-waste was shipped illegally. A more recent Interpol investigation uncovered that one in three shipping containers leaving the EU were carrying e-waste. Criminal investigations were launched against 40 companies. Illegal shipping increases container shipping costs since insurance firms have to cover legal costs. Cracking down on electronic waste benefits everyone. Although electronics aren't carried in reefer containers, they can still be transported in smaller boxes, when clients order shipping with an LCL quote.</p>





<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/4-export-of-ewaste.jpg" alt="Freigh-shipping-e-waste-export" width="1024" height="636" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-811" />





<p>Perhaps, with a global population more focused than ever before on solving climate change, we can find a better way to reuse and recycle our e-waste than illegally cause environmental problems in someone elses backyard.</p>



<p>The bulk of human waste ends up in landfills, usually within the country that creates the waste in the first place. OECD countries produce around half the worlds 2.6 trillion pounds of garbage, with East Asia and Pacific (EAP) region countries responsible for 21%. </p>





<p></p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/5-waste-pile-sea-freight.jpg" alt="landfill" class="size-full wp-image-813" /></a>



<h3>What About Non-Electronic Waste?</h3>



<p></p>



<p>Food and paper constitutes 63% of solid waste, all of which is biodegradable and goes into landfills. According to World Bank data, only 1% of worlds waste is recycled. </p>



<p>Garbage that biodegrades, or is recycled, isnt the problem. Electronic waste on the other hand is a major problem on land and at sea, with the greatest danger to wildlife being plastics. </p>



<p>According to the Ocean Recovery Alliance, <em>85 percent of the world's plastic is not recycled.</em> </p>



<p></p>



<h3>Where Does Plastic Go? </h3>



<p>The worlds oceans.</p>



<img src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/6-ocean-debris.jpg" alt="Shipping ocean debris"  class="alignnone size-full wp-image-817" />



<p>Research from three separate studies demonstrates that there are 5.25 trillion pieces of plastic debris in the oceans. Around 269,000 tons is on the surface, with the rest pulled into the deep by gyres - systems of rotating ocean currents - or carried to distant shores. 

</p>



<p>Ocean debris tracking started around 30 years ago. Since then, advocacy groups and institutes have been set up to study this problem, with scientists largely agreeing that Marine debris, unlike global warming, should be an easy thing to deal with, says Peter Ryan, a zoologist at the University of Cape Town. </p>



<p>Improvements to shipping have already started to solve aspects of this environmental problem. Seabirds were often found eating or having ingested packaging pellets, commonly used in manufacturing and found spilling from ports and boats. Modern studies show that this has decreased over the past two decades. </p>



<p>Sea debris, like e-waste, is an out of sight - out of mind issue for developing countries. Emily Penn, skipper of Sea Dragon, a ship that carries scientists on debris expeditions said, The thing that shocks me every time is the fact that the ocean looks like it is clear blue water, speaking to National Geographic. <em>And then ... we pull out that sock at the end of the net and find it's full of thousands of fragments of plastic.</em></p>



<p>More and more, the issue of ocean pollution is becoming recognised throughout, and progressively, innovative ideas and missions like the <a href="http://www.seabinproject.com/" target="_blank">Seabin Project</a>, are finally coming about to help eliminate this problem.</p>





<p></p>



<iframe width="834" height="469" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/s3tjOEtoArg" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>



<p></p>



<p></p>





<p>Decades ago, wildlife documentary presenter, Sir David Attenborough started to warn humanity of the dangers of not recycling our garbage. Since then, the problem has only gotten worse in landfills of developing countries where discarded phones leak chemicals into the soil - poisoning local communities, and to the oceans - where trillions of pieces of plastic float around the surface. 

</p>



<p>How we treat our garbage contributes to climate change and environmental damage. As U.S. President Barack Obama mentioned recently at the climate change summit in Paris, France, The growing threat of climate change could define the contours of this century more dramatically than any other. World leaders have vowed to act, but all of us, from consumers to shipping lines, have a role to play to curb the dumping of electronic waste and plastics illegally.  </p>









<a class="free-assessment" href="https://kontainers.com/freeshippingassessment" target="_blank"><img  style="border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 8px 0 -0.5px #5b6b7c; margin-top: 28px;" src="https://kontainers.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/shipping-assessment-cta.jpg" alt="Free Shipping Assessment"  /></a>



]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
